submission.title: Shared Tray Protocol for Coordinated Overlay Interfaces
submission.overview:
I propose the development of a browser-level interface protocol that allows multiple overlays (e.g. assistants, wallets, chat tools) to register themselves into a shared, user-configurable tray, typically anchored in the lower-right corner of the screen. This would support coexistence of decentralized tools, prevent UX collisions, and empower users to customize their digital environment without friction.

Overlays would be able to:
- Register a ‚Äústartup icon‚Äù and metadata (name, role, permissions)
- Indicate availability or priority
- Respect a shared system for tray placement and visibility
- Defer to user preferences in display and ordering

Users could:
- Configure which overlays are pinned or expanded
- Access others on demand via an expandable tray
- Rely on consistent placement and behavior across sites and browsers

Next Steps: I suggest forming a W3C Community Group to define an open standard for overlay registration and tray coordination. This standard could help browsers and web apps harmonize decentralized UI layers, supporting both open innovation and excellent UX.

submission.overview:
This analysis examines how trust.txt‚Äîa machine-readable, decentralized trust declaration protocol‚Äîaligns with Meta-Layer's criteria for trustworthy, interoperable systems. It evaluates key areas: decentralized namespaces, provenance, transparency, and governance. trust.txt provides a robust, decentralized method for publishers and associations to declare verified trust relationships. It is lightweight, extensible, privacy-respecting, and leverages existing domain infrastructure. It aligns strongly with core Meta-Layer principles around provenance (DP15), transparency (DP14), decentralized identity (DP5), and data sovereignty (DP4). Extensions to handle AI (datatrainingallowed=) and social URIs show proactive evolution (DP3, DP12). Adoption remains in early-to-mid phase: endorsements from bodies like DCN and AAM support growth, but broader platform integration (search, networks, programmatic ad systems) is still needed to achieve maximal effectiveness.

By facilitating machine-readable provenance data, trust.txt aids algorithms in assessing content trustworthiness and mitigating spread of misinformation.
It exposes affiliations, control relationships, and vendor/customer links‚Äîvisible both to users and platforms. Reciprocal declarations reinforce verified transparency.
Control is verified through hosting files at canonical domain roots, using HTTPS, signed redirects and cache-control. Reciprocal validation helps prevent spoofing.
Network effects matter: member associations and publishers list each other, strengthening trust signals when files reciprocate. As adoption grows, provenance networks become richer.
